title: American Airlines apologises after rejecting war veteran's service dog
text:
American Airlines apologises after rejecting war veteran's service dog Last updated 11:49, September 23 2015 Facebook 
Jason Haag, a former Marine who served tours in Iraq and Afghanistan, and his dog, Axel. 
American Airlines has apologised to a veteran after staff refused to let his award-winning service dog to board a flight with him. 
Captain Jason Haag, a former US Marine who served tours in Iraq and Afghanistan had been in Los Angeles on Sunday (local time) at an awards ceremony for service dogs where his German shepherd, Axel, received the top honour. 
Haag, a recovering alcoholic who suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) was paired with Axel in 2012 through K9s for Warriors . 
Well ladies and gentlemen we have been denied access and not been allowed to board our plane by American Airlines due to... 
First Coast News reported that Haag, his wife and Axel were scheduled to fly home to Fredericksburg, Virginia after the event but were stopped before boarding. 
An American Airlines gate agent reportedly told Haag demanded proof that Axel was a real service dog. 
"Well I answered all their questioned but didn't provide "paperwork" because 1) it's illegal to ask for and against federal law 2) I don't carry it because I've never had issue 3) I called ahead and everything was fine 4) but I did provide an ID to try and appease them. But to no avail," Haag posted on his Facebook page. 
Haag continued, "They had my wife in tears in front of 200 people as they brought more managers over to try and bully us." 
The former Marine said that he and his wife had been waiting in the gate area for two hours with their dog and were never question ahead of time. 
Axel was wearing a special service dog vest and harness in compliance with the airline's policy regarding service animals.
